text: Is it not a pleasure, having learned something, to try it out at due intervals?
context: On the joy of learning and practice

text: To go beyond is as wrong as to fall short.
The gentleman understands what is moral. The small man understands what is profitable.
context: On moral character versus material gain

text: If you would govern a state of a thousand chariots, you must pay strict attention to business, be true to your word, be economical in expenditure, and love the people.
When we see men of worth, we should think of equaling them; when we see men of a contrary character, we should turn inwards and examine ourselves.

At fifteen, I set my heart on learning. At thirty, I established myself. At forty, I had no more doubts. At fifty, I understood the mandate of Heaven. At sixty, my ear was attuned. At seventy, I could follow my heart's desire without transgressing what was right.
context: On the stages of life and wisdom

text: The gentleman is distressed by his lack of ability, not by the fact that men do not recognize his ability.
If language is not correct, then what is said is not what is meant; if what is said is not what is meant, then what ought to be done remains undone.
context: On the importance of precise communication

text: The gentleman calls attention to the good points in others; he does not call attention to their defects. The small man does the opposite of this.
context: On noble character and treatment of others

text: Learning without thinking is useless. Thinking without learning is dangerous.
context: On the balance of learning and reflection
